Award.AwardTitle: Timescales of Deep and Shallow Magmatic Evolution of Mt. Mazama (Crater Lake)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Timescales of deep and shallow magmatic evolution of Mt. Mazama (Crater Lake)

Intellectual merit. Arc magmatism is a major process whereby continents form, and caldera-forming eruptions can have substantial impact on global climate. Crater Lake is a representative example of arc-related calderas and is very well studied in terms of the geologic history and nature of eruptive products. However, such caldera-style eruptions seldom occurred at other Cascades volcanoes, and this study aims to understand why this is the case. This project aims to increase understanding of two aspects of arc magmatism: [1] the role of the lower crust, and particularly young mafic crust, in moderating and attenuating the ascent of magmas; and [2] the rate at which large magma bodies develop in the upper crust. Feedbacks between lower and upper crustal magmatic processes will be explored at Mt. Mazama (Crater Lake), with the goal of understanding differences in magmatic evolution at Mazama viz a viz other Cascades stratovolcanoes. Research will follow three approaches: [1] Use of U-Th and Re-Os isotopes, coupled with Sr-Nd-Pb isotopes and trace elements, to evaluate magma interactions with mafic lower crust. This approach is sensitive to involvement of garnet and can help constrain thermal and compositional characteristics of the lower crust. [2] Use of U-Th and O isotopic data to evaluate young volcanic deposits erupted in the last ~100 kyr. U series data are sensitive to hydrothermal processes, and will be used to constrain the size of the hydrothermal system associated with the pre-climactic magma chamber. [3] Use of U-Th isotopes to determine residence times of the crystal cargo in evolved eruptive units associated with the climactic caldera-forming eruption. These approaches will be used to estimate overall dimensions of the magma chamber that fed the climactic eruption at Mt. Mazama and formed the summit caldera, and to better understand the plumbing system and magmatic processes operating at this volcano.

Broader impacts. The proposed work will foster collaborations between UW-Madison, USGS, Carnegie-DTM, and US National Park Service on a volcanic system that potentially poses significant geologic risk. Outreach activities will include K-12 teacher workshops at Crater Lake National Park.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Cascades are commonly characterized as a “hot arc” based on the slow subduction of the relatively young Juan de Fuca and Gorda plates. High melting temperatures for primitive lavas are expected to promote extensive melting and assimilation of lower crust, but documenting crustal interaction, particularly lower crust, has proved difficult. Understanding the contributions of mantle and crust to arc magmatism is important for determining the rate at which the continents grow, as well as the mechanisms by which magmas evolve to compositions that produce explosive eruptions. Using U-Th and O isotopes, we documented extensive crustal interaction in the Crater Lake magmatic system, both in the deep crust (accompanied by production of garnet during dehydration melting of amphibolite and associated Th excess), as well as the upper crust (as traced by O isotopes and U enrichment, both produced by a shallow hydrothermal system. At Crater Lake, a caldera-forming eruption occurred at 7.7 ka, associated with eruption of ~50 km3 of primarily rhyodacitic magma.

 

In the final year of the grant, we pursued a comparative study of Mt. Shasta, which also included eruption of three large magmatic episodes of comparable size and duration as Crater Lake, yet none of the Shasta eruptions produced a pyroclastic caldera. The isotopic results from Shasta are distinct from those of Crater Lake in that U-Th and Sr isotope data from Shasta document a larger lower crustal component relative to Crater Lake, and evidence for shallow crustal interaction is comparatively minor at Shasta. This contrast logically follows the fact that Crater Lake produced a pyroclastic caldera, supporting models where caldera-forming eruptions reflect extensive residence time in the shallow crust. It is more difficult, however, to determine the fundamental reason why the Shasta magmatic system did not evolve a large shallow magmatic system. One possibility is the strong structural control in magma compositions as Shasta, which may have promoted rapid ascent and eruption of magmas from the lower crust.

 

Understanding why some large-volume volcanic systems produce eruptions that form pyroclastic calderas, and why other large systems produce primarily lava flows, remains a key unsolved problem in mitigating volcanic hazards and the climate effects of volcanic eruptions.
